name: Numbers With Same Consecutive Differences
title: Numbers With Same Consecutive Differences
content:
Given two integers n and k, return an array of all the integers of length n where the difference between every two consecutive digits is k. You may return the answer in any order.

Note that the integers should not have leading zeros. Integers as 02 and 043 are not allowed.

 

Example 1:

Input: n = 3, k = 7
Output: [181,292,707,818,929]
Explanation: Note that 070 is not a valid number, because it has leading zeroes.

Example 2:

Input: n = 2, k = 1
Output: [10,12,21,23,32,34,43,45,54,56,65,67,76,78,87,89,98]

 

Constraints:

  • 2 <= n <= 9
  • 0 <= k <= 9

discussion_posts.name: AnnieW
discussion_posts.content:
As in the problem discripition:
1 <= N <= 9 
0 <= K <= 9
There are 9 eligible values for N and 10 values for K, so there are at most 90 combinations, just curious what could the other 2 test cases?

discussion_posts.name: Eradicator
discussion_posts.content: Can someone explain how you compute the "absolute difference between every TWO consecutive digits" when working with ONE-digit numbers? The Expected value for every value of K when N is one is the set of all single digits. In what world does that make sense?
